name: Hair Lit Vol. 1
description: A collection short fiction inspired by classic Hair Metal songs featuring stories from Ryan W. Bradley, Chip Creek, Lindsay Hunter, Roxane Gay, Tobias Carroll, B.J. Hollars, Kyle Beachy, and many more. Edited by Nick Ostdick.

name: Most Likely You Go Your Way and I'll Go Mine by Ben Tanzer
description: This is the story about relationships, between father and son, friends, and most importantly between two newly formed couples. Following the lives and thoughts of four people in their mid-twenties, already experienced in dating, but starting to wonder if that one person is out there. Taking a look inside the thoughts and conversations on both sides of the fragile world of romance and pain, friendship and fear, and life in New York. Most Likely... is filled with culture, laughter, quasi-advice, and the idea of wanting everything, but knowing nothing. As the characters seek advance, their confusion mounts, emotions break down and get rebuilt, and the reader is left to wonder if men and women will ever really learn how to love. Check out Most Likely… at Orange Alert Press here.

name: Sunlight at Midnight, Darkness at Noon. The Cunningham/McCreesh Letters
description: Sunlight… is a collection of letters between two poets who have never met face to face. Written in 2002, these letters were never meant for public consumption, but when collected form a story of friendship. It is a discussion that explores poetry, craft, politics, and social criticism in intimate and stark detail. This item will be available on May 25th, but you can preorder here

name: Prose. Poems. A Novel
description:
Collection of stories that when pulled together tell a fascinating story of a young man's journey. With full color illustrations from Christy Call, this debut effort from Atlanta's Jamie Iredell is a classic in the making. 

(excerpt)
California cameras eyeball a Western landscape. The distant mesas are enormous tables. A gangly actor—and by this I mean that under the make-up, in real life, he is fat, short, and pimplefaced— saunters into the saloon, swinging his dusty be-pistoled leg, the bar backgrounded, miles away. The patrons hush—even the piano sitter, who adorns an unplaying piano, for the Stephen Foster will later be dubbed in. Cut. I’ll smoke this cigar. Give me a damsel. Someone guzzle a beer. This should be Atlanta, ca. 2006. Towers tower for a skyline. Now this is a
Western. The script begins: A whiskered goon at a notepad. Tumbleweeds. Crickets.
